Award.AwardTitle: CAPTIVATE: Collaboratory Achievement Project To Impact the Value of Architecture & Engineering Technology Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Los Angeles Pierce College Engineering Graphics & Design Technology (EG&DT) and Architecture Technology (AT) programs are bridging the disconnect between learning and perceived relevance by providing students with opportunities to develop and implement solutions to problems in their community. The project replicates professional experiences while providing direct benefits to society as students design and implement solutions to existing problems in a multidisciplinary, collaborative environment. The Collaboratory Achievement Project To Impact the Value of Architecture & Engineering Technology Education (CAPTIVATE) develops a program where students engage with effective role models, have culturally responsive experiences, and recognize the EG&DT and AT programs as a pathway to professions with social impact. This approach benefits students, campus, employers, and the community.

Los Angeles Pierce College is working to engage EG&DT and AT students in an experiential learning environment that fosters students' intrinsic motivation in order to advance them toward a credential and strengthen their 21st century skills, particularly problem-solving and collaboration. CAPTIVATE coordinates curricular and extracurricular projects consisting of six key components: project-based learning, multidisciplinary collaboration, real-world connection, community partnerships, tangible impact, and environmental sustainability. Los Angeles Pierce College will strengthen its partnerships with area businesses by aligning curriculum with workforce needs, and providing a conduit for meaningful engagement across the sector. Los Angeles Pierce College is developing a replicable framework that includes generalized and project specific outcomes. Models developed through this project will be shared with other institutions and faculty that are looking to make meaningful change in their programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CAPTIVATE project was initially a two-year grant which continued for a third year under a no-cost extension.  The goal of the project was to engage Engineering Graphics and Design Technology and Architecture Technology students in an interdisciplinary project-based collaborative laboratory to foster student engagement, motivate students to advance toward a credential, and strengthen students? problem solving and collaboration skills. The project focused on student engagement as a tool to increase 21st century skills, particularly problem solving and collaboration.    

CAPTIVATE was developed as a way to respond to a rapidly changing work environment, by engaging students in multidisciplinary projects with community stakeholders, that address issues that resonate with these students.  During the project work, students engaged with project stakeholders, instructors, and their peers. The project strengthened partnerships with local industry and helped to align curriculum with workforce needs while providing a conduit for meaningful student engagement.  Authentic project based Collaboratory projects can be an effective strategy for increasing community college capacity to adapt to rapid change. 

The CAPTIVATE project achieved its primary goal by establishing ?the Collaboratory? as a hub for creative problem solving, addressing community needs through student projects that develop and implement solutions. 74% of students reported that working on Collaboratory projects increased their motivation in their classes. In addition, pre and post surveys show positive gains in students? self-reported skills in problem solving and collaboration. Data collected during the project showed that students overwhelmingly dislike working in groups (in one pre-workshop survey, 100% of students stated they disliked working in group).  Helping students to develop a toolbox of specific strategies led to students feeling optimistic about their abilities to successfully work in teams (96% of students reported feeling more optimistic in one survey). These results show students gained significant and measurable skills for success in the workforce, having developed both technical skills and practical expertise such as problem-solving and collaboration.

The project team produced a handbook that provides a framework for engaging students, faculty, and the community in Collaboratory-style projects. The project team also created a website which includes a repository for faculty and others to submit and view project ideas.  The Collaboratory model can be replicated across disciplines, and shows promise in motivating students and improving necessary 21st century skills such as teamwork, collaboration, and problem-solving. 

Additionally, implementation of Collaboratory projects created mutual benefit to students and the local community, with projects that addressed water capture in drought prone areas, the reduction of waste through composting systems, and the development of urban farming systems for campus food production to support students facing food insecurity.  These projects led students to recognize their potential to positively impact their local community and society as a whole.

 


Last Modified: 10/04/2019
Modified by: Elizabeth P Cheung
